The NAEB offices are in Washington, D. C. The move of the
tape network is predicated on the concept of control and,
more significantly, development of educational radio net¬
work broadcasting.
The service is now being used by more than 150 stations.
A growth pattern of affiliates has been clearly established.
The tape network (initiated in 1951) is nearing a time when
it must adjust to technological change.
This change will occur when it becomes possible to economi¬
cally distribute educational radio programs to most (but not
all) stations by live interconnection. The need for a tape
production and duplicating facility will continue as a distri¬
bution means for music programs, other high fidelity material
and some programs that can sustain time delay without loss
of content values.
The establishment of the Public Affairs Bureau in Washington,
D. C. is mandated by the identification of the city as the
principal news producing locale in the world. Until live
interconnection is financially supported, (through free or
low cost telephone interconnection charges or by foundation
